Method 1: Chinese Remainder Theorem

Theorem 4.4.2

Let m1,m2,â¯,mnm_1,m_2, \cdots , m_nmâ1ââ,mâ2ââ,â¯,mânââ satisfy

Then the system (*) has a unique solution module
m=m1m2â¯mnm = m_1 m_2 \cdots m_nm=mâ1ââmâ2âââ¯mânââ

Aâ¡B(mod m)A \equiv B (mod \space m)Aâ¡B(mod m)

Example 1

Solve

xâ¡2(mod 3)x \equiv 2 (mod \space 3)xâ¡2(mod 3)
xâ¡3(mod 5)x \equiv 3 (mod \space 5)xâ¡3(mod 5)
xâ¡2(mod 7)x \equiv 2 (mod \space 7)xâ¡2(mod 7)

e.g.
m=3â5â7=105m = 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 = 105m=3â5â7=105
m1=5â7=35m_1 = 5 \cdot 7 = 35mâ1ââ=5â7=35
MÂ¯1=â1\bar M_1 = -1âMâÂ¯âââ1ââ=â1

 \space 

MÂ¯2=3â7=21\bar M_2 = 3 \cdot 7 = 21âMâÂ¯âââ2ââ=3â7=21
Need MÂ¯2Need \space \bar M_2Need âMâÂ¯âââ2ââ

MÂ¯3=3â5=15\bar M_3 = 3 \cdot 5 = 15âMâÂ¯âââ3ââ=3â5=15

MÂ¯3=1\bar M_3 = 1âMâÂ¯âââ3ââ=1

Check
x=a1M1MÂ¯1+a2M2MÂ¯2+a3M3MÂ¯3x = a_1M_1 \bar M_1 + a_2M_2 \bar M_2 + a_3M_3 \bar M_3x=aâ1ââMâ1âââMâÂ¯âââ1ââ+aâ2ââMâ2âââMâÂ¯âââ2ââ+aâ3ââMâ3âââMâÂ¯âââ3ââ
   =(2)(35)(â1)+(3)(21)(1)+(2)(15)(1)\space \space \space = (2)(35)(-1) + (3)(21)(1)+(2)(15)(1)   =(2)(35)(â1)+(3)(21)(1)+(2)(15)(1)
   =23\space \space \space = 23   =23
